Award.AwardTitle: Very High Energy Particle Astrophysics with VERITAS
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Universe is host to myriad sources that emit electromagnetic radiation at gamma-ray energies. These very high energy photons are produced in processes involving particles with energies beyond the reach of any ground-based accelerator. Gamma-ray observations can therefore be used to study the highest energy phenomena in the Universe. With this award, the University of Minnesota group will continue their work with the VERITAS gamma-ray observatory. The activities funded through this award will contribute to maintaining the VERITAS capabilities and sensitivity. This work will also contribute to the study of known blazars and the discoveries of new blazars, a class of Active Galactic Nuclei. The scientific goals are to study the astrophysical processes that generate gamma-ray emission in blazars and the links to the origin of observed ultra-high energy cosmic rays. The University of Minnesota group will mentor undergraduate students through the university's Research Experiences for Undergraduates program. Members of the group will continue to present VERITAS science at local astronomy clubs, high schools and other public outreach events such as the weekly public observing nights at the campus observatory.

The major objectives and methods to be employed by the University of Minnesota group include: (1) development of improved analysis techniques including implementation of a multivariate analysis toolkit and a new effort in better spectral reconstruction; (2) scientific analysis on Active Galactic Nuclei utilizing new spectral analysis techniques with a focus on locating the source of gamma-ray emission in blazars and understanding the origin of ultra-high energy cosmic rays; (3) coordination of multi-wavelength data campaigns in conjunction with VERITAS including efforts with Fermi, IceCube and HAWC; and (4) calibration and data quality monitoring tasks that include improvements on understanding of the instrument energy scale through a detailed study on the impact of atmospheric conditions on the reconstructed energy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Minnesota VERITAS team seeks to understand the mechanisms by which certain Active Galactic Nuclei known as blazars emit gamma-ray radiation above 100 GeV in large-scale jets of plasma emanating from the central black hole in the galaxy. Since blazars emit across all wavebands ? from radio to optical to X-ray and gamma-ray - the approach used comprises gathering data from all these wavebands to investigate the potential correlations between them. These data are then used to test the dominant theory that gamma rays are emitted from a blob of electrons that are accelerated perhaps due to a shock within the plasma jet. The accelerated electrons produce synchrotron radiation which itself scatters on the same electron population producing higher-energy photons up to gamma rays. To test these models, the UMN team led the successful effort to detect unusual flaring episodes from classic known blazars as well as to discover new blazars including those where the angle of the jet is mis-aligned with respect to the direct line to Earth.  Results from this work show that in many cases, but crucially not in all, this so-called synchrotron self-Compton model works well in explaining the gamma-ray emission. These data will be used by modelers to develop more refined theories to explain the range of gamma-ray behavior observed in blazars.

To support the above research, the UMN VERITAS team developed and implemented critical software components including the main analysis package used by the entire VERITAS collaboration for multiple research aims. 

The UMN VERITAS team also led the successful citizen science project Muon Hunter which used the Zooniverse platform to gather over 2 million volunteer classifications on 140,000 images to determine whether an image contained a muon ring or not, and if so, to draw an outline around the muon ring. Muon rings are by-products of air showers that are detected by the VERITAS cameras and due to their regular properties can be used to calibrate the VERITAS system. However, the software to select them can be cumbersome so the idea behind Muon Hunter was to train a deep learning algorithm to do better at selecting muons. Deep learning algorithms need quite a lot of training labels and the citizen science project was able to provide these very successfully. Future Muon Hunter projects will investigate ways to improve the speed at which these labels are gathered.
